keyTakeAways: A steel cable in the Glória funicular in Lisbon failed and snapped, leading to a deadly crash that killed at least 16 people and injured several others.
The cable did not meet the certification standards required by CARRIS, the operator of the funicular, and failed to meet the operator’s own specifications.
The Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) identified serious failures in the cable, maintenance, and braking systems.
Maintenance tasks were falsely marked as completed, even though they were not performed, and the maintenance plan was recorded as compliant despite non-compliance.
The preliminary report is not conclusive, and a final report is expected to be released next year.
Eyewitnesses described the crash as chaotic, with one man named Bruno describing it as 'a toy being thrown' from side to side, noting loud screams, a bang, and brown smoke.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A deadly funicular crash in Lisbon, Portugal, in September 2025, resulted in at least 16 fatalities and multiple injuries when a steel cable snapped during operation on Calçada da Glória. Preliminary findings from the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) reveal that the cable failed to meet certification or operational specifications set by CARRIS, the funicular’s operator. Additional failures include incomplete or falsified maintenance records, with tasks marked as completed despite non-performance. Eyewitnesses, including a man named Bruno, described the descent as chaotic and uncontrollable, with a loud bang and visible smoke. The interim report is not final, and a comprehensive final report is expected to be released next year.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
